column2: INSEE reports that 69% of 15–64-year-olds were in the labour force (recensement). Since 15–19 and 60–64 have much lower participation than 20–60
column3: the same year’s 20–60 rate would be a few points higher—roughly ~72%#1975: ~73–76%. Prime-age activity was very high for men but much lower for women (25–49: men ≈97%
column4: women ≈61%)
column5: pulling the combined 20–60 rate into the mid-70s.

column1: #INSEE also notes that in 1962 only 40–45% of women aged 30–50 were active (men near 95% at those ages)
column2: which is consistent with a combined 20–60 LFPR in the low 70s.

column1: #1990: ~77–80%. Women’s participation rose; youth and early seniors were still comparatively less active. (Use INSEE “séries longues” to pin the exact mix.)
#2000: ~79–82%. Continued rise in women; seniors just starting to pick up.
#2010: ~81–83%. Stronger participation for 50–59; overall 15–64 activity hovered around low-70s then.

column3: 50–64 ≈72.0%; weighting toward 20–60 (so a bit higher than 50–64
column4: a bit lower than 25–49) lands in the low-/mid-80s.
